docs.lead_paragraph: Whom will Professor Gingrich lecture this time?

headline.main: What to Look for in Tonight's Debate

docs.abstract: Newt Gingrich's performance is sure to be closely watched in a Republican presidential debate on foreign policy and national security.
docs.snippet: Newt Gingrich's performance is sure to be closely watched in a Republican presidential debate on foreign policy and national security.

docs.lead_paragraph: The F.D.A. says Avastin doesn’t work for breast cancer patients.  So why is Medicare still paying for it?
docs.abstract: Joe Nocera Op-Ed column finds it absurd that many health care insurers, including Medicare, continue to cover the costs for the breast cancer drug Avastin even after the Food and Drug Administration withdrew its approval of the medication.
docs.snippet: The F.D.A. says Avastin doesn’t work for breast cancer patients.  So why is Medicare still paying for it?

docs.lead_paragraph: Beset by insurance costs and desperate to make sure that drivers pass health tests, trucking companies and industry groups are working to persuade them to change their habits.

headline.seo: A Hard Turn: Big-Rig Drivers Focus on Getting Healthy
headline.main: A Hard Turn: Better Health on the Highway
headline.print_headline: A Hard Turn: Better Health On the Highway

docs.abstract: More truck drivers are choosing to eschew traditionally unhealthy lifestyle of their profession, as trucking companies offer incentives for them to lower blood pressure, stop smoking and lose weight; sedentary nature of job and lack of healthy food options have led to eighty-six percent of truck drivers being overweight or obese, fact that has significantly raised insurance costs for their employers.
docs.snippet: Beset by insurance costs and desperate to make sure that drivers pass health tests, trucking companies and industry groups are working to persuade them to change their habits.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Jessica Haley's 28th birthday in June, she posted a wish on the fund-raising Web site IndieGoGo. Ms. Haley and her husband, Sean, of Melbourne, Fla., wanted a baby, but their insurance did not cover fertility treatment. To their astonishment, donations started pouring in. Word of the couple's plight spread on Twitter and Facebook, and a ''Help the Haleys Have a Baby'' campaign raised $8,050 -- including $423 from a total stranger.

headline.main: Patients, Too, Turn to the Internet for Fund-Raising

docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope Well column notes online fund-raising is starting to spread to world of costly health care, allowing individuals to undergo procedures they could not otherwise afford by means of packaged donations; one Web site, IndieGoGo, has accepted dozens of campaigns, ranging from fertility treatment to organ transplants. Photo (M)
